description: A simple, hearty, and nutritious staple dish of finely sliced collard greens slowly sautéed with onions and tomatoes until tender and flavorful. Its name translates to 'stretch the week', as it's an affordable way to make meals last.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Sukuma Wiki is arguably the most important leafy green vegetable in Uganda and neighboring Kenya. Its name, which means 'to push the week' in Swahili, highlights its role as an affordable and reliable food that helps families stretch their meals and budget through the week. It is a constant presence on dinner tables, valued for its nutrition, affordability, and versatility.

ingredients.name: Collard Greens
ingredients.notes: Stems removed, leaves stacked, rolled, and finely sliced (chiffonade)

utensils.name: Large Pot or Skillet with Lid

steps.instruction: Wash the collard greens thoroughly. Remove the tough central stem from each leaf. Stack the leaves, roll them tightly, and slice them very thinly (this is called a chiffonade).
Heat the vegetable oil in a large pot or skillet over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until soft and translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the chopped tomatoes and optional curry powder. Cook for 5-7 minutes, mashing the tomatoes with the spoon, until they form a thick paste and the oil begins to separate.
Add all of the sliced collard greens to the pot. It will be a large volume but will cook down significantly.
Add the water and salt. Stir well to combine the greens with the tomato and onion base.
Cover the pot and reduce the heat to low. Let the greens simmer for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they are tender and have darkened in color.

cooking_indicators.visual: Greens will wilt completely and turn a dark, vibrant green.

steps.instruction: Remove the lid and, if there is excess liquid, increase the heat to let it evaporate for a few minutes. The dish should be moist but not soupy.
Taste and adjust salt if needed. Serve hot.
Serve the Sukuma Wiki hot as a side dish.

serving_suggestions: The essential companion to Ugali (Posho). Also served with Rice, Chapati, or Matoke. Always paired with a source of protein like grilled meat, fish, or beans.
